Sandwich-type Co core@shell nanocomposite (SiO2 @Co@CeO2): Coke resistant catalyst toward CO2 reforming with ethanol Feifei Li a Mingyue Wang a Jinming Zhang a Xingtao Lin b ⁎ Dazhi Wang a ⁎ Weijie Cai Supervision a ⁎ a Faculty of Light Industry and Chemical Engineering, Dalian Polytechnic University, 116023 Dalian, China Faculty of Light Industry and Chemical Engineering, Dalian Polytechnic University Dalian 116023 China Faculty of Light Industry and Chemical Engineering, Dalian Polytechnic University, 116023 Dalian, China b Faculty of Environment and Life, Beijing University of Technology, 100124 Beijing, China Faculty of Environment and Life, Beijing University of Technology Beijing 100124 China Faculty of Environment and Life, Beijing University of Technology, 100124, Beijing, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The design of highly efficient catalysts for CO2 reforming with ethanol is of great interest due to the serious coke deposition and the sintering of active metal. In this work, sandwich-type Co core@shell catalyst (SiO2 @Co@CeO2) with Co nanoparticles between SiO2 core and CeO2 shell was synthesized by strong electrostatic adsorption method. Interestingly, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst exhibited the outstanding activity/stability toward CO2 reforming of ethanol in comparison with Co-SiO2 catalyst. A bi-functional mechanism involving active sites on CeO2 shell was proposed. Indeed, cobalt nanoparticles between SiO2 core and CeO2 shell maintained the high dispersion because of the confinement effect, which supplied a stable Co-ceria interface area where the reaction occurred. In addition, CO2 could readily react with the O vacancies in CeO2 shell to form surface oxygen species and CO, which allowed a continuous cleaning of coke. These positive factors could make it as an attractive candidate for dry reforming process. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords SiO2 @Co@CeO2 Ethanol dry reforming Confinement effect Syngas Coke resistant 1 Introduction In the past decade, global warming mainly caused by the enormous discharge of the greenhouse gas CO2 has been one of the major concerns to maintain sustainable development [1]. To be addressed this issue, great efforts have focused on the physical capture and chemical utilization of CO2 to diminish its detrimental impact [2,3]. Among the developed techniques for CO2 value-added conversion, CO2 reforming with ethanol (EDR, C2H6O + CO2 →3CO + 3 H2) is regarded as an interesting process compared to methane dry reforming (CH4 + CO2 →2CO + 2 H2) [4]. One side, EDR approach could convert CO2 into high-valued syngas, a suitable feedstock for downstream Fischer-Tropsch process [5]. On the other hand, ethanol reactants derived from the renewable biomass such as corn or agriculture residues are more available and greener in comparison with fossil fuel methane, thereby meeting with the sustainable development [6]. However, the research about EDR process is still limited in spite of the above merits. Therefore, it is of great interest to investigate EDR reaction for CO2 depletion and syngas production. Up to date, enormous research has focused on the design of the active and low-cost transition metal-based catalysts with resistance to coking/sintering for dry reforming process, especially for Ni and Co [7–9]. Due to the high C-C bond rupture capacity, Ni-based catalysts have been widely studied [10,11]. However, the fast deactivation because of coke build-up might be a major hurdle for the industrial application of these systems. The encapsulated carbon on the catalyst surface could lead to the blocking of active metal or reactor blockage, thereby resulting in the decline of catalytic activity. Typically, Boudouard reaction, methane decomposition as well as polymerization of ethylene are regarded as the main routes of carbon formation, as depicted by Ruocco et al. [12,13]. To resolve this problem, they elucidated that 30 wt% of ceria loading in PtNi/SiO2-CeO2 catalyst could display the lowest coke formation rate. Meanwhile, other strategies have been developed to improve catalyst stability. Indeed, the addition of the appropriate noble metal could enhance the catalyst resistance towards deactivation [14]. On the other hand, it was reported that the selection of the suitable catalyst precursors might inhibit catalyst deactivation [15]. On the other hand, Co-based catalysts, another transition metal candidate, have been depicted with good coke resistance under dry reforming conditions [16]. Apart from the type of active metals and support, the performance of catalysts applied in dry reforming reaction also greatly relied on the preparation method [17]. The physicochemical properties such as particle size, morphology structure as well as metal-support interaction could be improved via the utilization of advanced preparation methods. It is generally accepted that catalysts with core@shell structure exhibit the better anti-sintering features to obtain the higher dispersion of active metal and the catalytic activity mainly depend on the synergistic interaction between core and shell [18–20]. In addition, it has been depicted that the particle size of active metal is of key importance in coke resistance [21]. Indeed, sintering of active metal to form larger particles in high temperature reforming reactions is regarded as one of the major reasons of carbon deposition. To be addressed this issue, catalysts with various core@shell structures such as yolk@shell, multicore@shell, sandwichtype core@shell etc. have been successfully fabricated for dry reforming process [22–24]. It was depicted that Ni@SiO2 catalysts in which Ni nanoparticles were embedded in SiO2 spheres presented better activity/stability than Ni/SiO2 samples [25]. The confinement effect of SiO2 might retard the aggregation of Ni nanoparticles as well as coke formation. Simultaneously, Ni@TiO2 [26], Ni@ZrO2 [27] and Ni@Al2O3 [28] have been designed and showed attractive stability. However, most of the above studies might focus on the Ni-based catalysts and the related research to confine the Co species is still in its infancy. So far, few reports on Co-based catalysts with core@shell structure are reported. Apart from this, CeO2 oxide with high redox capacity is regarded as an attractive dopant for catalyst modification in dry reforming reaction [29]. The adsorption/activation of reactant CO2 might occur in the oxygen defect sites of CeO2 to form the mobile O species which facilitate the dynamic coke elimination [30]. In this work, sandwich-type Co core@shell structure catalyst (SiO2 @Co@CeO2) was synthesized via a strong electrostatic adsorption method (SEA). Controlling the pH value of the impregnating solution above the point of zero charge of silica support might result in the deprotonation of the surface hydroxyl groups. Consequently, the silica surface was negatively charged, and cationic cobalt precursors could be strongly adsorbed, thereby enhancing the metal-support interaction and active metal dispersion [31,32]. Interestingly, the as-prepared SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst exhibited higher activity/stability in EDR process compared to Co-SiO2 sample synthesized by impregnation method. Catalysts were characterized in detail by XRD, BET, SEM, TEM, H2-TPR, Raman and XPS technique to establish the relationship between the physicochemical properties and the catalytic performance. Both the importance of the sandwiched core@shell structure and CeO2 promoter in minimizing the sintering of Co nanoparticles and coke deposition were also elucidated in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Materials Chemicals of C2H5OH, Co (NO3)3.6 H2O, CeCl3.7 H2O, NH3·H2O (aqueous, 25%−28%), hexamethylenetetramine (99%), tetraethylorthosilcate (TEOS) were purchased from Aladdin and Macklin Chemical Reagent. All chemicals were used without further pre-treatment. 2.1.2 Preparation of SiO2 nanosphere SiO2 nanospheres were prepared by Stöber method as reported in the previous literature [33]. 8 mL TEOS was firstly added into 280 mL ethanol. Subsequently, a mixture containing 8.4 mL ammonia water and 50 mL deionized water was added to the above solution and reacted for 24 h under constant stirring at room temperature. After that, the mixture was centrifuged, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and finally dried at 100 °C for 12 h. 2.1.3 Preparation of SiO2 @Co catalyst A strong electrostatic adsorption technique was used to synthesize SiO2 @Co catalyst. Indeed, 8 mL TEOS was added to 280 mL ethanol. A mixture containing 8.4 mL ammonia water and 50 mL deionized water was then added to the above solution. After reaction for 24 h under magnetic stirring, 4.1 g cobalt nitrate hexahydrate was added and the mixture was heated to 70 °C until the pH value was equal to 7. After that, the precipitation was thoroughly washed with the hot deionized water and calcined at 700 °C for 3.5 h. The catalyst was denoted as SiO2 @Co in the following discussion. 2.1.4 Preparation of SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst A mixture containing 0.6 g SiO2 @Co and 0.57 g cerium trichloride heptahydrate were added to 100 mL ethanol. After the addition of 10 g hexamethylenetetramine which was dissolved in the deionized water, the solution was heated to 70 °C and kept for 7 h. The solid was centrifuged, washed and dried at 60 °C overnight. The catalyst was calcined at 700 °C for 3.5 h and labeled as SiO2 @Co@CeO2. 2.1.5 Preparation of Co-SiO2 catalyst Co-SiO2 was synthesized by conventional impregnation method for comparison. Typically, cobalt nitrate hexahydrate was dissolved in ethanol and the achieved solution was added to SiO2 nanosphere as prepared in the above discussion. After dried at 90 °C overnight, the solid sample was calcined in air at 700 °C for 3.5 h to obtain Co-SiO2 catalyst. 2.1.6 Preparation of Co/CeO2-SiO2 catalyst Co/CeO2-SiO2, another reference catalyst, was synthesized by the same impregnation method. Indeed, a precursor mixture containing cobalt nitrate hexahydrate and cerium trichloride heptahydrate were dissolved into ethanol and the solution was added to the as-prepared nanosphere SiO2. The mixture was dried at 90 ℃ overnight. Finally, the solid sample was calcined in air at 700 °C for 3.5 h to obtain Co/CeO2-SiO2 catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Morphology structures of the catalysts were probed using a JEM-2100 (UHR) transmission electron microscope (TEM). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected on a JSM-7800 F Thermal field emission scanning electron microscope. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of the calcined catalysts were carried out on a ZHD-TPX-6 apparatus. 100 mg sample was firstly degassed with a N2 flow at 200 °C for 20 min. After cooling down to room temperature, the tests were conducted from 25 °C to 750 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C /min under a flow of 5 vol% H2/N2. The metal composition was probed by an inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry technique (ICP-AES) operated on an OPTIMA 8000 setup. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by an X-ray diffractor (XRD-7000 s, Japan) using Cu-K α radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The operated voltage and current were 40 kV and 30 mA, respectively. The samples were scanned at 2 θ range between 10° and 70° and the scanning speed was 10°/min. N2 adsorption desorption isotherms were conducted on an ASAP 2460 setup to measure the specific surface area of catalysts. The pore size distribution was calculated according to the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Raman spectra were used to analyze the coke deposition of the spent catalysts. The measurements were conducted using a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope. The laser as the excitation source was 514 nm and laser intensity were 2 mW. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed to determine the valence states and surface features of the catalysts. The samples were tested using a Thermo VGscientific ESCA MultiLab-2000 equipment. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic reforming of ethanol with CO2 was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor (8 mm of internal diameter) under atmospheric pressure. Prior to test, the samples (100 mg, 40–60 mesh) were insitu reduced at 500 °C for 1 h with a 5 vol% H2/N2 flow (40 mL/min). After purging with a N2 flow, ethanol dry reforming reactions were carried out from 500 °C to 750 °C with a stoichiometric feedstock (C2H6O/CO2/N2 =1/1/1.5, molar ratio; 33.3 wt% of CO2 in mass) to investigate the influence of reaction temperature on catalytic performance. The inert gas N2 was used as diluted gas and internal standard gas. The space velocity (GHSV) was set as 27,700 mL gcat−1h−1. The effluent gas after reaction was monitored online by gas chromatography (GC) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Ethanol conversion and product selectivity were calculated based on the following equation: (1) X EtOH = C EtOH ( in ) − C EtOH ( out ) C EtOH ( in ) × 100 % Where C EtOH ( in ) and C EtOH ( out ) corresponded to the molar flow of ethanol in inlet and outlet gas, respectively. (2) S x * = C x ( outlet ) ∑ C i ( outlet ) × 100 % Where S x * referred to the selectivity of the product x and C i ( outlet ) indicated the molar concentration of the product i in the outlet dry gas (except H2O and CO2). 3 Experimental and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure analysis Scheme 1 demonstrated the stepwise preparation of the core@shell structure catalysts. Silica nanospheres were synthesized as core and then cobalt nanoparticles were deposited on the SiO2 surface (SiO2 @Co). When the outer shell was coated with ceria, sandwich-type catalyst (SiO2 @Co@CeO2) was generated. Morphology structure of the calcined catalysts was determined by TEM technique. As shown in Fig. 1a, the silica nano-spheres with the diameter size ranging from 160 to 180 nm were observed, which could act as an inert support for the deposition of Co and Ce to form hybrid core@shell structure catalyst. For SiO2 @Co core-shell sample, it was clear to see that Co nanoparticles with 7–12 nm sizes were decorated on the outside of the silica spheres (Fig. 1b,c). Moreover, silica sphere still maintained the original morphology, suggesting its structural stability. With respect to sandwich-type SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst, SiO2 @Co was further coated with a CeO2 layer using precipitation method to investigate the dopant effect of ceria. As depicted in Fig. 1(d,e), small CeO2 nanocrystals were decorated on the catalyst surface. The thickness of sandwichtype structure catalyst was thicker than SiO2 @Co without CeO2 layer. In addition, the sizes of the nanoparticles around silica cores were obviously smaller than those in SiO2 @Co catalyst. This revealed that during the calcination process, Co species might interact with CeO2, thereby leading to its higher dispersion and smaller particles [34]. Herein, the aggregation of Co nanoparticles decorated on the SiO2 nanosphere surface (SiO2 @Co) occurred during the calcinations process. However, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 stabilized the cobalt particles via the encapsulation by CeO2 shell. Upon reduction, a clear layer of CeO2 was formed, covering the cobalt particles as marked in Fig. 1h. To further elucidate the detailed structure information, HRTEM images of SiO2 @Co@CeO2 are also depicted in Fig. 1g. Obviously, Co3O4 nanoparticles embedded by CeO2 particles were observed, thereby evidencing the successful synthesis of sandwich-type core@shell catalyst. Indeed, the lattice fringe depicted a spacing of 0.23 nm corresponded to the (222) plane of Co3O4 nanocrystals [35], whereas the lattice fringe of 0.27 nm was in indexed with the (200) plane of cubic CeO2 [36]. Besides, the interface between Co3O4 and CeO2 nanoparticles marked in Fig. 1g implied that the cobalt species were incorporated into CeO2 lattice and a synergy effect was generated in the sandwich-type Co core-shell catalyst. More importantly, for the supported catalysts, a metal oxide@metal core@shell nanoparticle was believed to improve the catalytic behavior in high-temperature reactions, considering the positive role at the oxide-metal interface and the anti-sintering features. Similarly, a sandwich-type SiO2 @Pt@SiO2 catalyst was prepared via the deposition of Pt nanoparticles on silica nanospheres, which were further encapsulated by SiO2 shell [24]. The designed catalyst exhibited the high thermal stability and excellent resistance to deactivation. TEM images of Co-SiO2 synthesized by conventional impregnation method (Fig. 1i) revealed the significant aggregation of Co species and no Co particles were observed around the silica nano-spheres, implying the unsatisfactory Co dispersion and weak metal-oxide interaction. FESEM images are further collected to determine the morphology and composition of the as-obtained catalysts. It was noted that the silica spheres were well-dispersed for the core@shell structure catalysts ( Fig. 2a,b). Typically, the rough surface implied the successful deposition of Co3O4 particles and ceria on the SiO2 surface in consistent with the previous report [37]. Moreover, the energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) results illuminated that SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst mainly contained Co, Si, Ce and O elements and all elements were evenly scattered. The similar findings were obtained for SiO2 @Co sample as depicted in Fig S1. As measured by ICP-OES technique, the actual Co loading for the fresh SiO2 @Co catalyst was 26.0 wt%. The as-prepared SiO2 @Co was selected as core to prepare the sandwichtype SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst. Therefore, the Co concentration for SiO2 @Co@CeO2 sample was less (17.1 wt%) because of the presence of Ce (14.5 wt%). On the other hand, the concentration of cobalt in Co-SiO2 sample was 25.1 wt%. In order to check the effect of CeO2 layer on the redox capacity, H2-TPR analysis were carried out for the SiO2 @Co and SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalysts. The profiles are presented in Fig. 3. As for SiO2 @Co sample, two main reduction peaks centered at ca.340 °C and 542 °C, respectively. Considering that it was difficult for SiO2 to be reduced in the investigated temperature region, the observed reduction peaks were mainly attributed to the reduction of cobalt species. Hence, the first reduction peak was related to the continuous reduction of small, dispersed Co3O4 nanoparticles (Co3O4 →CoO→Co). It was reported that after reduction of Co3+ species to Co2+, immediately reduction of Co2+ species to metallic Co0 occurred [38,39]. Another broad peak at 542 °C might probably be assigned to the reduction of bulk Co3O4 nanoparticles with broad particle size distribution [40]. In particular, the obvious difference was noted in the TPR profile of SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst. Indeed, the reduction peaks of sandwich-type SiO2 @Co@CeO2 shifted to lower temperatures compared to SiO2 @Co. Herein, the peak at 331 °C corresponded to the reduction of small cobalt particles, whereas the peak at 440 °C and 635 °C might represent the combined reduction of bulk Co3O4 species and CeO2 shell [41]. This finding confirmed that the presence of Co-Ce-O interface could facilitate the reduction of the Co3O4 nanoparticles. Moreover, the calculated hydrogen consumption of SiO2 @Co (5.56 mmol/gcat) was close to the theoretical value for the complete reduction of Co3O4 nanoparticles to metallic Co species (5.87 mmol/gcat). Actually, it was accepted that SiO2 core was difficult to be reduced in the region of the investigated temperatures. On the contrary, the experimental H2 consumption for SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst (7.03 mmol/gcat) greatly surpassed the theoretical value. More hydrogen consumption probably corresponded to the reduction of the CeO2 species. The synergy effect between Co3O4 and CeO2 shell could improve the catalyst reducibility and oxygen mobility, thereby resulting in higher catalytic behavior. It was accepted that the incorporation of Co species into CeO2 crystal structure might lead to lattice deformation and the generation of O vacancies which facilitate the adsorption/activation of CO2 reactant as well as the coke cleaning in EDR reaction. XRD patterns of the calcined catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. The main diffraction peaks of the SiO2 @Co sample corresponded well to the Co3O4 phase (JCPDS#42–1467). More importantly, the band at 20–25 ° assigned to the amorphous silica phase was weak which might be caused by the cover of Co3O4 shell. This result indirectly evidenced the successful synthesis of core@shell catalyst. The similar finding was observed for the SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst. Apart from this, the peaks at 2 θ = 28.8°, 33.2°, 47.7°, 56.5°, 59.6° and 65.3° were attributed to the characteristic (111), (200), (220), (311), (222) and (400) reflections of fluorite-phase CeO2, respectively (JCPDS#34–0394). It should be noted that SiO2 @Co@CeO2 exhibited the relatively broaden peaks of Co3O4 phase in comparison with SiO2 @Co. This implied the formation of smaller cobalt particles after the addition of CeO2 layer. The mean crystallite sizes of Co3O4 calculated by the Scherrer equation were 7.90 nm and 5.92 nm respectively for SiO2 @Co and SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalysts ( Table 1), suggesting that the aggregation of Co3O4 was inhibited in the sandwich-type core @shell structure catalyst. Co3O4 nanoparticles were retarded to move outside the shell because of the presence of CeO2 shell and it was favorable to prevent the aggregation of the cobalt particles under calcination conditions [42]. Diffraction peaks for Co3O4 with more intensity were observed for the calcined Co-SiO2 catalyst and the calculated cobalt crystal size was 26.68 nm. Fig S2 shows XRD patterns of the ex-situ reduced catalysts. Obviously, the diffraction peaks became weaker in all cases. Characteristic peaks of Co3O4 were disappear while a tiny and broad peak attributed to CoO species were observed, indicating the partial re-oxidation of metallic Co0 sites due to the ex-situ reduction conditions. Moreover, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst presented the weaker and more broaden peak of CoO compared to SiO2 @Co and their average particles size were 4.13 nm and 5.12 nm, respectively. The result demonstrated that the strong interaction with CeO2 shell made the cobalt species to be more dispersed during the reduction process. Active cobalt particles were prevented to move outside the shell due to the presence of the slit-shaped framework of CeO2 shell. This positively reduced Co particles from aggregation with each other and inhibited their growth. Apart from this, the calculated lattice parameter of ceria in SiO2 @Co@CeO2 (5.39 Å) was slightly less than the value of pure CeO2 (5.41 Å), proving the incorporation of Co ions into CeO2 lattice structure considering that the ionic radius of Co3+ (0.65 Å) or Co2+ (0.74 Å) was smaller than that of Ce4+ ions (0.87 Å) [43]. Interestingly, partial cobalt ions diffused into ceria lattice structure and replaced Ce4+ ions via the interface diffusion during calcinations process because of the intimate contact between cobalt species and cerium species. Consequently, the diffraction peaks of cubic CeO2 moved to larger angle side. On the contrary, the position of diffraction peaks corresponding to Co3O4 phase was conversely shifted to lower region. Importantly, the smaller crystallite size that possessed more active sites was favorable to enhance the catalytic performance. On the other hand, the strong interaction between cobalt and ceria was beneficial for improving thermal stability and coke resistance in dry reforming. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm curves are presented in Fig. 5 to explore the textural features of the calcined catalysts. Both SiO2 @Co and SiO2 @Co@CeO2 showed type IV isotherms with a hysteresis loop, suggesting the presence of mesoporous structure. The distribution of pore size (inserted image) further confirmed this finding. As listed in Table 1, the calcined SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst possessed the less specific surface area as well as pore volume compared with SiO2 @Co, which was probably due to the deposition of CeO2 on the porous structure, thereby blocking some pores [44]. Interestingly, the average pore size (Table 1) for the SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst was still in the region of mesostructure, implying that the thin ceria shell might not cause massive diffusion resistance to the reactant and/or product molecules during dry reforming process. Indeed, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 sample with core-shell structure exhibited the less BET surface area while presented the better catalytic behavior. XPS spectra were collected to study the surface chemical states of the as-prepared catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6c, the less intensity of Co signal was observed for SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst in comparison with SiO2 @Co. It was well-accepted that XPS technique could be only suitable to determine the surface information of catalysts. Hence, this finding might evidence the sandwich-type core@shell structure of the SiO2 @Co@CeO2 sample, where cobalt nanoparticles were covered by a CeO2 shell and could not be detected by XPS surface technique. This result was in good line with the above discussion of the TEM images. Moreover, Ce XPS spectra of SiO2 @Co@CeO2 sample (Fig. 6b) could be further deconvoluted into ten peaks due to the existence of Ce 3d5/2 (labeled as v) and Ce 3d3/2 (labeled as u). The peaks at v, v’’, v’’’, u, u’’ and u’’’ were ascribed to Ce4+ species while the bands at v0, v′, u0 and u′ corresponded to the Ce3+ states. The values of binding energy were listed in detail in Table S1. This indicated the co-existence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ species on the catalyst surface. It should be noted that the presence of Ce3+ ions was generally related with the generation of O vacancies. Interestingly, more Ce3+ species in CeO2-based catalysts corresponded to more oxygen vacancies [45]. The concentration of Ce3+ ions could be calculated according to the following formula: Con (Ce3+) = A(Ce3+)/ [A(Ce3+) + A(Ce4+)], where A(Ce3+) and A(Ce4+) referred to the sum of the peak areas indexed to the Ce3+ and Ce4+ species, respectively [46]. Herein, the calculated value was 34.5% as depicted in Table S1. In comparison with the Ce3+ concentration reported in the previous literature such as Ni/CeO2 (16%) [47], CeO2 @Co3O4 (27%) [46] and CeO2 nanocubes (12%) [48], it could be concluded that sandwich-type structure in SiO2 @Co@CeO2 sample greatly increased the formation of Ce3+ ions because of the strong interaction between Co cores and CeO2 shell as evidenced by XRD and XPS findings. It was believed that larger amount of Ce3+ species could facilitate the coke gasification during dry reforming process to avoid carbon deposition. Previous reports elucidated that CO2 preferred to adsorb onto the Ce3+ sites instead of the oxidized Ce4+ sites [49]. O 1 s spectra of the catalysts are also displayed in Fig. 6. After the deconvolution, two main peaks at ca. 530.9 eV and 533.4 eV were observed in all cases, which were assigned to the lattice oxygen bonding to the metal cations ( O latt ) and the chemisorbed oxygen ( O ads ), respectively. The relative ratio of two types of oxygen species was quantified according to the peak areas. Importantly, the O ads / O latt value was calculated to be 3.55 for SiO2 @Co@CeO2, which was much larger than that of SiO2 @Co (0.99). From this, Ce-O-Co bands might be formed in sandwich-type structure catalyst (SiO2 @Co@CeO2), which facilitated the migration of internal lattice oxygen to surface oxygen species [45,50]. This further convinced the interaction between cobalt and CeO2, in line with H2-TPR analysis. This might be also caused by the presence of Ce3+ species as depicted in XPS findings, which was favorable for the generation of oxygen defects on the oxide surface [51]. Moreover, the higher concentration of surface oxygen species could result in better catalytic behavior for EPR reaction. 3.2 Catalytic activity and stability for ethanol dry reforming 3.2.1 Activity comparison The catalytic behavior of the investigated was probed for ethanol dry reforming with a C2H6O/CO2/N2 molar ratio of 1/1/1.5. Fig. 7 shows the ethanol conversion and product concentration for SiO2 @Co, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 and the reference Co-SiO2, Co/CeO2-SiO2 catalysts, respectively. Indeed, Co-SiO2 catalyst exhibited the lowest activity. The unsatisfactory activity might be interpreted by the aggregation of Co particles as observed from TEM image (Fig. 1i). On the other hand, the addition of CeO2 (Co/CeO2-SiO2) might only enhance ethanol conversion to some extent. On the contrary, another two catalysts with core@shell structure depicted the better catalytic behavior. Actually, SiO2 @Co catalyst presented the higher ethanol conversion than that of the reference samples (Co-SiO2, Co/CeO2-SiO2). The strong metal oxide-metal interaction arising from the electrostatic adsorption method endowed the SiO2 @Co catalyst with better activity. More importantly, no byproduct acetone was detected for SiO2 @Co@CeO2 sample which also exhibited the highest ethanol conversion. This might be explained by its higher reducibility and the better dispersion of active Co species as supplied by H2-TPR, TEM and XRD results. It was accepted that cobalt metal possessed the higher capacity of C-C bond dissociation, which could make the fast decomposition of intermediates acetaldehyde instead of the formation of acetone via aldolization process. Moreover, a synergistic effect between Co3O4 and CeO2 shell in the unique sandwich-type core@shell structure might also contribute to the better performance. H2/CO ratio obtained over the SiO2 @Co@CeO2 was relatively less, which could be explained by the higher CO2 conversion on CeO2 shell to CO and active O species due to the existence of oxygen vacancies [52,53]. To optimize the operation temperature of ethanol dry reforming, the influence of reaction temperature was further studied for SiO2 @Co@CeO2 in the wide range of 500 °C to 750 °C. Complete ethanol conversion was achieved at 500 °C, implying its high low temperature activity. The molar concentration of H2 in the outlet dry gas gradually declined with increasing temperature, while another targeted product CO followed the reverse trend. This might be due to the occurrence of the RWGS reaction (CO2 + H2 →CO + H2O) that was thermodynamically favorable at the high temperature. Upon heating, the concentration of byproduct methane decreased, which indicated the occurrence of methane dry reforming (CH4 +CO2→2CO + 2 H2). 3.2.2 Stability tests Fig. 8 presents the stability tests of the as-prepared catalysts for EDR reaction at 650 °C. The reason to conduct the tests at the relatively high temperature was because coke deposition was enormous at low temperature for dry reforming process [54]. Typically, Co-SiO2 catalyst exhibited an initial decline of ethanol conversion as well as the increase of CH4 concentration, suggesting the occurrence of deactivation. Additionally, the carbon accumulation was severe which blocked the reaction tube within 23 h and increased the reaction pressure, thereby preventing the injection of the feedstocks. The reactor blocking problem also occurred for another reference catalyst Co/CeO2-SiO2 after 35 h time-on-stream tests. The results indicated that the existence of CeO2 doped by the impregnation technique only prolonged the catalyst stability to some extent. It was reported that coke formation was mainly due to Boudouard reaction (2CO →C + CO2) and methane decomposition (CH4 →C + H2) [55]. In contrast, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst maintained the stable activity with time on stream. Reactor pressure did not increase during stability tests, avoiding the absence of reactor blocking by carbon deposition. SiO2 @Co catalyst also exhibited the good stability during the whole time. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts XRD patterns of the spent catalysts are shown in Fig S3. A diffraction peak at 26.4° was detected, which was attributed to graphic coke [56]. More importantly, the intensity increased following the order: SiO2 @Co@CeO2 <SiO2 @Co< Co-SiO2. This result revealed that sandwich-type core@shell structure in SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst greatly inhibited the carbon formation during the reaction. Besides, peaks for the face-centered cubic metallic Co0 species were also observed at 44.2° and 51.5° because of the reduced atmosphere. In addition, the diffraction peaks of SiO2 @Co@CeO2 sample were weaker and broader than the others, implying its smaller particle size. It demonstrated that the CeO2 shell could efficiently prevent the sintering of Co nanoparticles even after the long testing time. The calculated mean crystallite size of metallic cobalt was 6.78 nm (SiO2 @Co@CeO2), 8.67 nm (SiO2 @Co) and 17.32 nm (Co-SiO2). The decline of particle size for used Co-SiO2 catalyst compared to the fresh sample might be due to the cover of particle surface by the enormous coke. XRD findings depicted that sandwich-type Co core@shell catalyst exhibited the remarkable resistance to carbon deposition and metal sintering. TEM images of the used catalysts are displayed in Fig. 9. Whisker carbon were formed around the used SiO2 @Co (Fig. 9a,b) and the carbon nanotubes with cobalt particle at the tip were observed (Fig. 9c), suggesting that the filamentous coke detached Co particles from silica support and destroyed the catalyst structure. Moreover, Co nanoparticles were encapsulated by coke, thereby preventing the adsorption/activation of the reactants and leading to catalyst deactivation. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 9d, no extensive formation of whisker coke was found for the used SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst and only slight sintering occurred compared to the fresh catalyst, reaffirming its structural stability. A clear CeO2 shell as marked in Fig. 9d further proved the successful synthesis of sandwich-type catalyst. Moreover, the formed carbon nanotubes were not intimate contact with Co nanoparticles (Fig. 9f). It was accepted that oxygen vacancies in CeO2 shell could facilitate the adsorption/activation of CO2 to form the mobile O species, thereby enhancing the insitu gasification of coke [57]. As to the used Co-SiO2 sample, the severe sintering of Co particles occurred (Fig. 9g) and the large amounts of coke covered the catalyst surface (Fig. 9h). This might be caused by the larger cobalt particle size and weaker metal-support interaction as elucidated in the above discussion. The massive growth of filamentous carbon could lead to the blocking of the reactor bed as observed in stability tests (Fig. 8). Fig. 10 shows the Raman spectra of the used catalysts to probe the type and graphitic degree of coke deposition. A band at1349cm−1 was attributed to the D band which was related to the disordered structural mode of the carbon species, while another band at 1581 cm−1 corresponded to the G band in association with the graphitic coke [58]. Indeed, the intensity of the spent Co-SiO2 catalyst was larger even after the shorter time test (23 h), thereby implying its faster rate of coke formation. Instead, the intensity of the used SiO2 @Co@CeO2 was less. Additionally, the intensity ratio of IG/ID, which was indexed with the graphitic degree of coke, increased in the following order: SiO2 @Co@CeO2 (0.97) < Co-SiO2 (1.2) <SiO2 @Co (1.51). Therefore, the less amount and lower graphitic degree of coke in SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst might contribute to its stable performance. Based on the above results, the CeO2 shell also took part in ethanol dry reforming process to improve catalyst performance. Therefore, a bi-functional mechanism was proposed for SiO2 @Co@CeO2 ( Fig. 11) while a mono-functional pathway contributed to SiO2 @Co and Co-SiO2. Indeed, the cobalt nanoparticles encapsulated by SiO2 cores and CeO2 shell maintained the high dispersion, keeping a stable Co-ceria interface area where the reaction occurred. Meanwhile, the absence of acetone further confirmed the rapid decomposition of acetaldehyde at the Co-CeO2 interface. In addition, CO2 could readily react with the O vacancies in CeO2 shell to form surface oxygen species and CO, which allowed a continuous cleaning of coke. To be concluded, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 with sandwich-type core@shell structure showed the excellent coke-resistance and anti-sintering feature, which made it as a promising candidate for ethanol dry reforming. The confinement effect of the CeO2 shell prevented the movement of tiny Co nanoparticles to aggregation ( Scheme 2). On the other hand, the high oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 shell could enhance the dynamic oxidation of carbon formed during dry reforming reaction. 4 Conclusion In this work, a sandwich-type core@shell catalyst (SiO2 @Co@CeO2) with Co nanoparticles between SiO2 core and CeO2 layer was synthesized using the strong electrostatic method and applied for ethanol dry reforming. Indeed, full ethanol conversion was obtained at 500 °C with as high as 55.1 mol% H2 and 17.8 mol% CO in the outlet dry gas. More importantly, no byproduct acetone was formed. In addition, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst presented the less metal sintering and coke deposition after 50 h stability tests while still maintaining the high activity. In contrast, SiO2 @Co sample without the CeO2 shell exhibited the less activity and higher carbon formation compared to SiO2 @Co@CeO2. Moreover, Co-SiO2 prepared by impregnation method possessed the larger Co particle size and showed the unsatisfactory activity as well as the massive coke formation that blocked the reactor tube within 23 h. The better catalytic performance of SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst might be attributed to the confinement effect provided by the core@shell structure and the high redox capacity of CeO2 shell. Typically, Co nanoparticles were encapsulated by silica and ceria and their mobility were prevented, thereby inhibiting their aggregation. Besides, the CeO2 shell could supply the mobile O species, thus facilitating the oxidation of coke formed during ethanol dry reforming. Hence, the finding might provide a simple strategy to develop the efficient catalysts for ethanol dry reforming and other high temperature reactions. coredata.dc:description: The design of highly efficient catalysts for CO2 reforming with ethanol is of great interest due to the serious coke deposition and the sintering of active metal. In this work, sandwich-type Co core@shell catalyst (SiO2 @Co@CeO2) with Co nanoparticles between SiO2 core and CeO2 shell was synthesized by strong electrostatic adsorption method. Interestingly, SiO2 @Co@CeO2 catalyst exhibited the outstanding activity/stability toward CO2 reforming of ethanol in comparison with Co-SiO2 catalyst. A bi-functional mechanism involving active sites on CeO2 shell was proposed. Indeed, cobalt nanoparticles between SiO2 core and CeO2 shell maintained the high dispersion because of the confinement effect, which supplied a stable Co-ceria interface area where the reaction occurred. In addition, CO2 could readily react with the O vacancies in CeO2 shell to form surface oxygen species and CO, which allowed a continuous cleaning of coke. These positive factors could make it as an attractive candidate for dry reforming process.
coredata.dc:title: Sandwich-type Co core@shell nanocomposite (SiO2 @Co@CeO2): Coke resistant catalyst toward CO2 reforming with ethanol
